communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 
December 5, 2023 Miriam Bhimani 154625-50160201@requests.muckrock.com 
RE: Chicago Public Schools FOIA Request N014501-111923 
Dear Ms. Bhimani: This letter is in reply to your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request seeking the following information: Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records: 

Since January 1, 2023 through current: 

1) Copies of all invoices from the The Law Firm Salvatore Prescott Porter & Porter, PLLC; 

2) Copies of records of payments by CPS/Chicago Board of Education to The Law Firm Salvatore Prescott Porter & Porter, PLLC. I want the actual bills as well as proof of payment by the district. 

3) Any and all letters of engagement between CPS/Chicago Board of Education and The Law Firm Salvatore Prescott Porter & Porter, PLLC, including any modifications or changes. RESPONSE : Documents responsive to your request are available to download via the CPS FOIA Center at www.cps.edu/FOIARequests . Please log in with your username and password to access the records. Please note that there are no records responsive to the third part of this request, as there are no new letters of engagement, nor modifications or changes to prior letters, within the timeframe specified in this request. Invoices have been redacted in accordance with section 7(1)(m) of the FOIA to remove information constituting privileged attorney-client work product. Section 7(1)(m) of the FOIA exempts from release “[c]ommunications between a public body and an attorney [] representing the public body that would not be subject to discovery in litigation, and materials prepared or compiled by or for a public body in anticipation of a criminal, civil, or administrative proceeding upon the request of an attorney advising the public body.” 5 ILCS 140/7(1)(m). Further, redactions were made to prevent “unavoidably disclos[ing] the identity of a confidential source, confidential information furnished only by the confidential source, or persons who file complaints with or provide information to administrative, investigative, law enforcement, or penal agencies.” 5 ILCS 140/7(1)(d)(iv). To the extent you consider this a denial, pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/9.5(a) you may file a Request for Review with the Public Access Counselor (PAC) at: Public Access Counselor; Office of the Attorney General; 500 South 2nd Street; Springfield, IL 62706.  You also have the right to seek judicial review of your denial by filing a lawsuit in the State circuit court; 5 ILCS 140/11. If you have any questions, please contact our office at (773) 553-3500. Thank you for your request. Sincerely, Annie Righi Freedom of Information Act Officer Chicago Public Schools

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: FBI Moore 11.29.23
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

You are receiving this correspondence as a request under the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. subsection 552. I am requesting the following:

Copies of all records, documents, and communications responsive to Mr. Robert Lowell Moore, Jr., aka Robin Moore (October 31, 1925 – February 21, 2008). He was an author of such books as The Green Berets, The French Connection, and Court Martial. All or some of this file has been released to a prior requestor(s); a portion was published by a now defunct blog, Entropic Memes, in 2008. Mr. Moore's case file number is identified by that requestor as 94-61092. Please see attached documents and the following link archived by the Internet Archive's Wayback Machine: https://web.archive.org/web/20160303165610/http://www.slugsite.com/archives/897

Therefore, I am requesting any parts of Mr. Moore's file that have been released previously and those not yet released.

Please conduct a cross-reference search for Mr. Moore. This would include any files the bureau may have on the Junta Revolucionaria Cubana, or JURE (Bureau file number 105-114543; Miami file number 105-6661).

There is no expectation of a violation of Mr. Moore's privacy, as he passed away on February 21, 2008. Privacy rights are not extended to deceased persons. Please see attached documents and the following link, for an obituary published by the New York Times on February 23, 2008: https://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/23/books/23moore.html

I am asking you waive any fees associated with this request. I am a member of the news media and request classification as such. My bylines, which include Unicorn Riot, the Geopolitical Economy Report, and Creem Magazine, can be found in both print and electronic publications. Please take note of the Office of Management and Budget guidelines published March 27, 1987 (52 FR 10012) that include electronic publications and other nontraditional publishers as representatives of the news media.

A fee waiver is appropriate in situations where "disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest because it is likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of the operations and activities of the government, and is not primarily in the commercial interest of the requester,” 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(iii). Per the bureau's prior release of Mr. Moore's file, at least one bureau memo, dated May 5, 1965, states of The Green Berets, "classified information is contained in Moore's book."

The Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) monitored Mr. Moore in this period as well. Please see a clip of press coverage about The Green Berets, attached, which was archived by the CIA shortly after the May 5, 1965 bureau memo. This document can found in the CIA's CREST system and in the Reading Room on its website: https://www.cia.gov/readingroom/docs/CIA-RDP75-00149R000700610012-8.pdf

Understanding how the bureau and other agencies handled investigations into journalists and writers who covered or disclosed the actions of American intelligence agencies is in the public's interest.

In the event that there are fees, I am willing to pay up to $100. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

This request is not being made for commercial purposes. All documents will be provided to the general public without charge.

I look forward to your response within 20 working days, as the statute requires. If access to the records I am requesting will take longer, please contact me with information about when I might expect copies or the ability to inspect the requested records.

If you deny any or all of this request, please cite each specific exemption you feel justifies the refusal to release the information and notify me of the appeal procedures available to me under the law.

If any potentially responsive records have been destroyed and/or transferred, then I request copies of the destruction or transfer slips as well as any other documentation relating to, mentioning or describing said destruction or transfer, to include but not be limited to confirmation that the bureau has no other copies of said records.

Sincerely,

Robert Skvarla, Jr.

    Please See attachment for description.

Supporting documentation **

Please be advised that efoia@subscriptions.fbi.gov is a no-reply email
address. Questions regarding your FOIA request may be directed to
foipaquestions@fbi.gov. If you have received a FOIPA request number, please
include this in all correspondence concerning your request. Please note eFOIPA
requests are processed in the order that they are received. If you have not
received a FOIPA request number, your request is in the process of being
opened at which time it will be assigned a FOIPA request number and
correspondence will be forthcoming.

**

Upon receipt of your FOIPA request number, you may check the status of your
FOIPA request on the FBIâ€™s electronic FOIA Library (The Vault) on the FBIâ€™s
public website, http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on the â€˜Check Status of Your
FOI/PA Request toolâ€™ link. Status updates are performed on a weekly basis. If
you receive a comment that your FOIPA request number was not located in the
database, please check back at a later date.

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Kurt Cobain Suicide Investigation
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Please provide any and all documents, reports, photos, and video recordings related to the suicide of Kurt Cobain that occurred in his Seattle, Washington residence on April 5, 1994.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Ryan Bronte (Student at Tulane University)
rbronte@tulane.edu

communications.subject: Public Records Center - Police :: P161533-112723
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 

12/05/2023 
 
Ryan Bronte 
155159-43515985@requests.muckrock.com 
 
RE: Public Disclosure Request#: P161533-112723 
 
Dear Ryan Bronte, 
 
Dear Ryan Bronte: 
This communication is in response to your public disclosure request received on November 27, 2023. 
Your requests seek records related to SPD’s investigation of the death of Kurt Cobain, all disclosable records associated with 94-16500, the investigation of the death of Kurt Cobain, are available online on the SPD Blotter at the following link: http://spdblotter.seattle.gov/2014/03/31/detectives-reviews-cobain-case-which-remains-closed/ 

That link is to the SPD Blotter which has an update on the case from March 15, 2016. Near the bottom of the page there are links to 4 PDFs and 1 Zip file which have the documents from the case responsive to your request. One of the PDFs contains an exemption log detailing redacted and withheld content and exemptions applied. 

Also as a courtesy, I have attached the Order Granting Summary Judgment, dated May 20, 2016, by King County Superior Court Judge Patrick Oishi, which permanently enjoins SPD from releasing any records from the case file regarding the death of Kurt Cobain that had not previously been disclosed; i.e., the records posted on the Blotter. I have also attached the Court of Appeals decision which upholds Judge Oishi’s decision. 
As such, we will now be closing this request. 
Thank you, 
Nina Afereti 
SPD Legal Unit 
 
If you have any questions, you may send a message using the Police Records Request Center or call the Public Disclosure Desk at 206-684-5481. 
 
Sincerely, 
Penina Afereti 
Seattle Police Department 
Legal Unit 
 
SPD receives between 7, 000 and 8, 000 public records requests annually and is processing between 2, 500 to 3, 000 open requests at any given time. This may result in a slower than anticipated response to your request. Thank you for your 
patience. 
 
As a reminder you can login at the Police Records Request Center where you can access Police online information, manage your profile, submit record requests, track your request status, receive and send messages, make payments, view frequently asked questions, and download your records.

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Police Logs
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

PDF police log Media Bulletins from 10/22/2023 through today
PDF police log Media Bulletins every week, posted on cloverdale.net Civic Plus website and in the City of Cloverdale's weekly email, "The Cloverdale Newsletter"

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Molly Fisher

Good Morning Molly Fisher,

In response to your request for Public Records, dated November 30, 2023, attached you will find Media Bulletins.  In one batch you will find November 21, 2023 to Sunday November 26, and Monday November 27 to Monday December 4, 2023.

As far as the Media Bulletins that are posted weekly to the Cloverdale Newsletter and the City of Cloverdale's Weekly Newsletter, I have attached a months worth of files.  You should know that is it the same information that you requested in both files.  If you are wanting to receive this information on a weekly basis, you can just email the dispatch center at : clodispatch@ci.cloverdale.ca.us  It is published weekly Monday to Sunday.

This completes your Public Requests Act request of 5/30/2023

Respectfully,

Linda Webb
Police Records Manager
Administrative Assistant to the Chief of Police
Cloverdale Police Department

communications.subject: RE: California Public Records Act Request: Police Logs
communications.communication:
Hi,

Thanks so much for your help with this request! I especially appreciate learning how to receive these without relying on the cloverdale.net website.

Sincerely,
Molly Fisher

title: Child care provider data 2019-present (Department of Human Services)

communications.subject: Rhode Island Access to Public Records Act Request: Child care provider data 2019-present (Department of Human Services)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Rhode Island Access to Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Historical licensing data for all licensed child care providers (active and closed) that were open anytime from 1/1/19-present:
1) Provider name or ID
2) Provider address
3) Latest license issue date and expiration date 
4) First license issue date
5) Enrollment, including dates on which enrollment was recorded (by child age groups if available)
6) Capacity, including dates on which capacity was recorded (by child age groups if available)
7) Prices, including dates on which prices were recorded (by child age groups if available)
8) Quality Rating and Improvement System (QRIS) scores, including dates on which scores were recorded
9) Any additional provider data that your agency collects

If electronic records from before 1/1/19 are available, I’d be happy to collect them as well.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Gabrielle Pepin

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: DOL FOIA Protocols
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

On behalf of the #DetentionKills Transparency Initiative of Al Otro Lado, I hereby request copies of any agency records showing the policies and procedures DOL FOIA Officers require WHD personnel to follow in responding to FOIA requests. This should include training materials, PowerPoint presentations, tasking forms or templates for electronic tasking, and quality control resources. Any step-by-step instructions for what to do upon receiving a FOIA request will similarly be responsive to this request. 

Please task a search that only includes records policies and procedures that are currently in force.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Andrew Free

Boston, MA  02115     From:  Raymond E. Mitten Jr.  Counsel for FOIA Appeals, Paperwork Reduction Act, Federal RecordsAct Re: Your Appealto the Solicitor of Labor under the Freedom  ofInformation Act and/or Privacy Act. Date of your appeal:  May 26, 2023 Subject of yourappeal: “Policies and procedures required by FOIA officers for WHD personnel” Appeal Reference No.: 2023-A-00146 This is to acknowledge receipt of your letter appealing adenial of information by a Department of Labor component agency. Your appeal is being processed. The law requires that appeals be sequenced for action on afirst-in first-out basis, consistent with the guidance provided by thecourts.  See Open America v. Watergate Special Prosecution Force, 547 F.2d605 (D.C. Cir. 1976). The number ofappeals currently waiting for review is substantial. However, the Freedom of Information Actpermits multitrack processing of requests based on the amount of processingwork or time, or both, involved. 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(D)(i). Thus, we are authorized, to schedule forfaster action those appeals which require limited staff time – i.e., those thatinvolve limited scope or complexity. Should you have any questions about the status of your appeal,have any additional information which you believe should be brought to ourattention, or wish to limit or withdraw your appeal, please contact this officeat the phone or address listed above.  To help us serve you, please direct your inquiries to Vinela Marmolejos via email at Marmolejos.Vinela.M@dol.gov, or at the number noted above, andrefer to our appeal reference number when making your inquiry. Thank you.

communications.subject: Meeting Request: FOIA Request and Appeal 2022-F-13967
communications.communication:
Good afternoon Mr. Free,

I'd like to apologize for the lack of communication regarding the processing of FOIA 2022-F-13967. On behalf of, Michael Leiterman, the Branch Chief of Document Management & FOIA, we would like to request a meeting with you to discuss resolving your request and subsequent appeal.
The earliest available date would next Tuesday, between 12:00 EST and 2:30 EST (September 5th ), Would you be available sometime during this timeframe? The meeting itself shouldn't exceed 30 minutes. However, if this doesn't work for you, please let me know at your earliest convenience.
I also ask that you provide the best contact number to reach you at that time.

I appreciate your time and patience.

Best,
Melina Cintrón, BSc
Government Information Specialist

WHD<https://www.dol.gov/agencies/whd> | US DOL<https://www.dol.gov/?_ga=2.170356320.1340485049.1631634815-987571526.1631634815>

communications.subject: Re: Final Response Letter FOIA 2022-F-13967
communications.communication:
We appeal. 

This is a mandatory disclosure record that should have been released without a request in accordance with 5 USC 552(a)(2)(C). The b5 redactions are going to be the subject of a request for contempt if we are forced to litigate this.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #2022-F-13967
communications.communication:
We appeal. 

Exemption 5 does not apply to these materials, as they are instructions to staff affecting a member of the public which should have been affirmatively disclosed and indexed pursuant to 5 USC 552a2C. This search also appears to be inadequate and we appeal on that basis as well. 

Thank you, 

Andrew Free

title: Source Data for 2021 Birth Data Calculations

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Source Data for 2021 Birth Data Calculations
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

I am seeking all source data, both provisional and final, used in calculating the 2021 birth data as provided in response to FOIL request #23-03-192. This includes, but is not limited to:

	1.	Raw data sets, databases, or spreadsheets used as the basis for the 2021 birth data calculations.
	2.	Statistical methodologies, algorithms, or software tools used in processing and analyzing the 2021 birth data.
	3.	Any draft versions, preliminary calculations, or interim reports related to the 2021 birth data.
	4.	Communications or memos discussing challenges, discrepancies, or issues related to the collection, processing, or validation of the 2021 birth data.
	5.	Any records or communications that discuss reasons for the unavailability or delay in releasing birth data after 2019.

I understand that the New York State Department of Health has a legal obligation to respond to my request within 20 business days, as required by the FOIL law. If the department anticipates that it will be unable to provide the requested information within that time frame, I ask that you notify me in writing and provide an explanation for the delay, as well as a new estimated timeline for providing the responsive records.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jackson Parker

communications.subject: North Carolina Public Records Law Request: PBN Incident
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the North Carolina Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

According to local news reports, Detectives with the Fayetteville Police Department’s Cold Case Sexual Assault Unit made an arrest in September in connection with a 1997 sexual assault cold case. According to the report, using DNA technology not available in 1997 and collaborated with Parabon Nanolabs, Inc., the NC State Crime Laboratory, analysts with the FBI’s Violent Criminal Apprehension Program, and other members of Fayetteville Police Department’s Sexual Assault Cold Case Multidisciplinary Team. I am looking for:

-  Investigative reports, memos,  incident reports regarding this case
-  Any invoices, contracts, or MOUs, with Parabon Nanolabs
-  Any emails to or from representatives at Parabon nano labs.  "*@parabon.com"
-  internal Memos, communications, or presentations referencing "Parabon"
-  communications with the state crime laboratory referencing "parabon" or "snapshot"

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Dhruv Mehrotra

communications.communication:
Fayetteville, NC ************************************************************************ Record request #23-2126 has been closed. The closure reason supplied was: We have provided all publicly available records responsive to your request. The Public Records Act exempts from disclosure files when disclosure would constitute an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy, such as personnel, medical, or similar files. In the records we disclosed, we have redacted private information, such as social security numbers, addresses, and telephone numbers. The Public Records Act also exempts investigative case files from disclosure, including officer narratives, notes, BWC/In-car camera video, and crime scene photographs.  This completes the request. ************************************************************************ Questions about your request? communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: IAPro internal investigations (Port of Seattle Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I request the listing of internal investigations in IA Pro with columns:
 Occurred date    Case/CAD/Incident No    Employee ID/Serial number    First name    Last name    Date hired    Incident type    Allegation    Directive    Finding    Finding date    Action taken    Employee Type 

I request the listing be provided in Excel format so I can easily sort/filter it. Redactions should be done in Excel.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

communications.subject: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: State of Virginia Salaries 2023
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:


State of Virginia Fiscal Year 2023 Compensation Data for All Employees
Please provide the following fields for each employee in the dataset: 
Employee # | FIrst Name | Middle Name/Initial | Last Name | Employee Role Title | Position Number | Agency Name | Agency Location | Agency Address | Agency City/State/ZIP | Employee Category | Compensation (Base Pay, Salary, Hourly Rate, Total Pay, etc) | Overtime | Benefits Pay | Date Hired | Date Terminated | FT/PT 

Note:  If not all fields listed above are releasable as public record or available please disregard those individual fields for this request.

I would prefer the request be filled electronically, by either e-mail attachment or FTP Download if available, otherwise sent through mail via CD/DVD. I would appreciate the request to be filled in an accessible format, including but not limited to: CSV, Excel, Microsoft Access database, or other bulk list file type.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Tom Nash, a citizen of Virginia, in coordination with Tyler King.

communications.subject: RE: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: State of Virginia Salaries 2023
communications.communication: Good afternoon, I just had a couple questions regarding the data provided. I was curious if this dataset is representative of the 2023 fiscal year (from 7/1/2022 - 6/30/2023) as requested, or if the data provided was an as-of "snapshot" based on the report run date? I ask because it appears there are several employees with "Company Seniority Dates" and "Employees State Begin Dates" beyond the 2023 fiscal year. Can you also clarify which field should be considered the Employee Start Date, and may we also get a list of non-abbreviated "Companies"?

communications.subject: RE: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: State of Virginia Salaries 2023
communications.communication:
Good morning, 

I wanted to follow up on my previous email from 8/30 regarding the effective date of the data provided as well as a list of non-abbreviated "Companies". 

I also wanted to inquire about a record count discrepancy between this data and data previously released by this office in response to a separate request for 2022 employee compensation data. 2022's data had over 110,000 employee records released while this year has about 55,000 employee records. Looking at some specific employees existing in 2022 that do not exist in the 2023 data, it appears that most of those records belong to "Faculty, University Staff, and Political Jurisdiction Staff" with record counts of those classifications having the approximate record count of the difference between the two files. 

Would you be able to clarify the effective date of the data (FY 2023 as requested, or a snapshot in time as of the run of the report), as well as the field that could be considered Employee Start Date? Would it be possible to include these records in the 2023 disclosure as they were provided in response to a separate request for 2022 employee compensation data?  If you could a "key" between the company abbreviation provided and their non-abbreviated descriptions/names, that would also be greatly appreciated. 

Best,
Tyler

communications.communication:
Hi Mecca, 

Thank you for speaking on the phone with me earlier today regarding my questions for this request. 

I have attached a file below that is a subset of the records provided to use previously for this request. This subset of records with highlighted rows exemplifies the question I had. 

The first tab "Comp Rates State + Non-State". My question regarding this was, in the case of an employee having both state and non-state comp rates, would their total pay be the two amounts added together? These rates are highlighted in orange in this tab. 

The second tab "Employee StartBeginDates"  highlights employee start/begin dates and seniority dates, some of which go beyond the FY2023 timeframe originally requested.  I was curious if this dataset is representative of the 2023 fiscal year (from 7/1/2022 - 6/30/2023) as requested, or if the data provided was an as-of "snapshot" based on the report run date? I would also like to ask which of these two dates should be considered an employee's hire date? 

Thank you!
Tyler K.

communications.communication:
Good evening. Please find the response below to recent follow up request.

Yes. Total pay for an employee would include the state comp rate, non-state comp rate, and special pay rate, if applicable.

The seniority date reflects total state service, the  employee start date is the most recent hire date.

communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 

11/01/2023 

Miriam Bhimani 
MuckRock News, DEPT MR153946 263 Huntington Ave 
Boston MA 02115 

Dear Miriam : 

RE: Chicago Public Schools FOIA Request N014429-110123 
Thank you again for using the Chicago Public Schools FOIA Center. 
Under the Freedom of Information Act, a public body may extend the time to respond to a FOIA request by up to 5 business days for a limited number of reasons. 5 ILCS 140/3(e). 
We are extending the time to respond to your request by 5 business days for one or more of the following reason(s): 
(  ) the requested records are stored in whole or in part at other locations than the office having charge of the requested records; 
( )  the request requires the collection of a substantial number of specified records; 
( ) the request is couched in categorical terms and requires an extensive search for the records responsive to it; 
( ) the requested records have not been located in the course of routine search and additional efforts are being made to locate them; 
(  ) the requested records require examination and evaluation by personnel having the necessary competence and discretion to determine if they are exempt from disclosure under Section 7 of this Act or should be revealed only with appropriate deletions; 
(x) the request for records cannot be complied with by the public body within the time limits prescribed by 5 ILCS 140/3 (c) without unduly burdening or interfering with the operations of the public body; 
( ) there is need for consultation, which shall be conducted with all practicable speed, with another public body or among two or more components of a public body having a substantial interest in the determination or in the subject matter of the request 
Sincerely, 

Annie Righi 
FOIA Officer 
Chicago Public Schools

communications.subject: Non-Commercial FOIA Request :: N014429-110123
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 
December 4, 2023 Miriam Bhimani 153946-57531332@requests.muckrock.com 
RE: Chicago Public Schools FOIA Request N014429-110123 
Dear Ms. Bhimani: This letter is in reply to your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request seeking the following information: Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records: 

Records sufficient to show the following: 

1. Contents of emails and attachments highlighted on attached email log released via FOIA N014357-101523. RESPONSE : Documents responsive to your request are available to download via the CPS FOIA Center at www.cps.edu/FOIARequests . Please log in with your username and password to access the records. Under the rules of FOIA, private information and unique identifiers contained within public records are exempt from public disclosure; those portions have been redacted including date of birth, social security number, parents’ names, birth place, race/ethnicity, employee identification number, vital records’ identification numbers, signatures, school transcripts, and other highly personal information. Pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/7 (1)(b), “Private information, unless disclosure is required by another provision of this Act, a State or federal law or a court order,” and pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/7(1)(c), “Personal information contained within public records, the disclosure of which would constitute a clearly unwarranted invasion of personal privacy, unless the disclosure is consented to in writing by the individual subjects of the information. “Unwarranted invasion of personal privacy” means the disclosure of information that is highly personal or objectionable to a reasonable person and in which the subject’s right to privacy outweighs the legitimate public interest in obtaining the information. The disclosure of information that bears on the public duties of public employees and officials shall not be considered an invasion of personal privacy. Further, redactions were applied to mask communications between a parent and their child’s school district pursuant to section 7(1)(c). Parents have a personal privacy interest under 5 ILCS 140/7(1)(c) in their identifying information when they contact their child’s school to express opinions. (See Ill. Att' y Gen. PAC Req. Rev. Ltr. 38873, issued June 30, 2016, at 4-5 and Ill. Att' y Gen. PAC Req. Rev. Ltr. 56488). Personally identifiable student record information has been redacted in accordance with the Illinois School Student Records Act 105 ILCS 10/1 et seq. and the corresponding Section 7.5(r) FOIA exemption (5 ILCS 140/7.5(r)). Redactions have been made pursuant to section 7(1)(f) which exempts from release “[p]reliminary drafts, notes, recommendations, memoranda and other records in which opinions are expressed, or policies or actions are formulated, except that a specific record or relevant portion of a record shall not be exempt when the record is publicly cited and identified by the head of the public body. The exemption provided in this paragraph (f) extends to all those records of officers and agencies of the General Assembly that pertain to the preparation of legislative authority.” 5 ILCS 140/7 (1)(f). Furthermore, this exemption is “intended to protect the communications process and encourage frank and open discussion among agency employees before a decision is made." State Journal-Register v. Univ. of Ill. Springfield, 994 N.E.2d 705, 713 (2013). Redactions were made pursuant to section 7(1)(v) of the FOIA, which exempts from release “[v]ulnerability assessments, security measures, and response policies or plans that are designed to identify, prevent, or respond to potential attacks upon a community's population or systems, facilities, or installations, but only to the extent that disclosure could reasonably be expected to expose the vulnerability or jeopardize the effectiveness of the measures, policies, or plans, or the safety of the personnel who implement them or the public. Information exempt under this item may include such things as details pertaining to the mobilization or deployment of personnel or equipment, to the operation of communication systems or protocols, to cybersecurity vulnerabilities, or to tactical operations.” 5 ILCS 140/7(1)(v). Finally, redactions were applied in accordance with section 7(1)(m) of the FOIA to remove information constituting privileged attorney-client work product. Section 7(1)(m) of the FOIA exempts from release “[c]ommunications between a public body and an attorney [] representing the public body that would not be subject to discovery in litigation, and materials prepared or compiled by or for a public body in anticipation of a criminal, civil, or administrative proceeding upon the request of an attorney advising the public body.” 5 ILCS 140/7(1)(m). To the extent you consider this a denial, pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/9.5(a) you may file a Request for Review with the Public Access Counselor (PAC) at: Public Access Counselor; Office of the Attorney General; 500 South 2nd Street; Springfield, IL 62706.  You also have the right to seek judicial review of your denial by filing a lawsuit in the State circuit court; 5 ILCS 140/11. If you have any questions, please contact our office at (773) 553-3500. Thank you for your request. Sincerely, Annie Righi Freedom of Information Act Officer Chicago Public Schools

communications.subject: Texas Public Information Act Request: McLennan County Administrator Dustin Chapman
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Payments from McLennan County to John Erwin and John Erwin Construction from January 1 2014 until January 1, 2022

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Bernadette Feazell

communications.subject: RE: [CAUTION:  BULK MAIL] Texas Public Information Act Request: McLennan County Administrator Dustin Chapman
communications.communication:

Thank you

communications.subject: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: FOIA Request: ARPA Funds
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

The Virginia Department of Criminal Justice Services awarded $75 million in American Rescue Plan Act funding as part of the Law Enforcement Equipment-Training Grant Program in order “to make one-time grants to state and local law enforcement agencies located in the Commonwealth, including colleges and universities, and, local and regional jails, for the purpose of training and purchasing equipment and supplies to support law enforcement related activities." https://www.dcjs.virginia.gov/sites/dcjs.virginia.gov/files/cjsb-materials/2023-05-11/Law%20Enforcement%20ARPA%20Grant%20Program.pdf

According to the press release from the Virginia Department of Criminal Justice Services, Chesterfield County was awarded $555,000 (grant application # 509833) as part of the Law Enforcement Equipment-Training Grant Program. 

Pursuant to the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A copy of all documents, including but not limited to, applications, agreements, and reporting documents related to the $555,000 received as part of the Law Enforcement Equipment-Training Grant Program.  

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Tom Nash, a citizen of Virginia, in coordination with e.

communications.subject: County Records Request :: R005914-111323
communications.communication:
Dear Tom Nash: 
This office is in receipt of your request for records made in accordance with the Virginia Freedom of Information Act (§ 2.2-3700 et. seq.). Receipt Date: November 13, 2023 Reference Number: R005914-111323 
Please allow five working days to process the request. Should we require additional time, we will inform you in writing. If there are fees associated with your request, we will inform you in writing prior to processing. Records Requested: “To Whom It May Concern:

The Virginia Department of Criminal Justice Services awarded $75 million in American Rescue Plan Act funding as part of the Law Enforcement Equipment-Training Grant Program in order “to make one-time grants to state and local law enforcement agencies located in the Commonwealth, including colleges and universities, and, local and regional jails, for the purpose of training and purchasing equipment and supplies to support law enforcement related activities." https://www.dcjs.virginia.gov/sites/dcjs.virginia.gov/files/cjsb-materials/2023-05-11/Law%20Enforcement%20ARPA%20Grant%20Program.pdf

According to the press release from the Virginia Department of Criminal Justice Services, Chesterfield County was awarded $555,000 (grant application # 509833) as part of the Law Enforcement Equipment-Training Grant Program.

Pursuant to the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A copy of all documents, including but not limited to, applications, agreements, and reporting documents related to the $555,000 received as part of the Law Enforcement Equipment-Training Grant Program.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Tom Nash, a citizen of Virginia, in coordination with E” 
You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you will receive an email when your request has been completed. Please note that Virginia Freedom of Information Act record request is a request for existing documents and does not require a governmental body to create new information, to do legal research, or to answer questions. 
Sincerely, 
Chesterfield County FOIA Request Office

communications.subject: [Records Center] County Records Request :: R005914-111323
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 

Good Morning Mr. Nash, 
We will be invoking the additional time allowed by law to respond to this request (VA Code 2.2-3704) of the additional 7 working days, due to the need to consult with multiple departments in response to your request as well as staffing limitations. 
Thank You, 
Tiffany Valenta 
FOIA Specialist valentat@chesterfield.gov (mailto:valentat@chesterfield.gov)

communications.subject: [Records Center] County Records Request :: R005914-111323
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 
Good Afternoon, Please log in to the Chesterfield FOIA Portal at the link below to retrieve records that are responsive to your request, with exemptions per VA Code §2.2-3706(B)(5) because they reveal specific tactical plans, the disclosure of which would jeopardize the safety or security of law-enforcement personnel or the general public, and §2.2-3706(B)(10) because they reveal investigative techniques or procedures and §2.2-3705.1(13) as they contain account and routing numbers with a financial institution. For questions regarding the denial of your request, please contact Karen Leonard (Records Administrator) at LeonardKJ@chesterfield.gov (mailto:LeonardKJ@chesterfield.gov) Thank You, Tiffany Valenta FOIA Specialist valentat@chesterfield.gov (mailto:valentat@chesterfield.gov)

title: Cell Phone Cracking - LBPD Cellebrite Documents

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Cell Phone Cracking - LBPD Cellebrite Documents
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act I am requesting copies of the following records:

- All engagement letters, contracts, vendor selection forms, sole source letters, technology request forms invoices, and purchase orders from CELLEBRITE USA dating from 2009-2013.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter in the time frame set out in the CPRA.

Christa Miller

communications.subject: PRA Request :: P013291-100323
communications.communication:
Dear Christa Miller: The Public Records (PRA) division does NOT process Police Reports, Arrest Reports or Subpoenas. These requests must be submitted to the Information Management (IM) division: https://www.longbeach.gov/police/how-do-i/request-a-police-report/  The IM division report request helpline is (562) 570-7381. If your PRA requests such records, it will be closed upon receipt.  Pursuant to California Government Code § 7922.535, staff will review your request and respond within 10 days to notify you if there are responsive records, or if an extension is necessary to determine if responsive records exist. If your request was received after business hours or on a weekend or holiday, the next business day will be considered the date of receipt. The 10-day response period starts with the first calendar day after the date of receipt (Ca. Civ. Code, § 10.). 
 
 
 
Thank you for your interest in public records of the Long Beach Police Department. Your request has been received and will be processed in the order it was received. Your request was received in this office on 10/3/2023 and given the reference number P013291-100323 for tracking purposes. 
 
Records Requested: "To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act I am requesting copies of the following records:

- All engagement letters, contracts, vendor selection forms, sole source letters, technology request forms invoices, and purchase orders from CELLEBRITE USA dating from 2009-2013.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter in the time frame set out in the CPRA.

Christa Miller

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Flong-beach-police-department-619%252Fcell-phone-cracking-lbpd-cellebrite-documents-152778%252F%253Femail%253Dlongbeachcapd%252540govqa.us&url_auth_token=AAAbwqaErL8xy5Q54U7Mg3DWRZI%3A1qntYL%3A9L7OmYHq_4YStW0JnnTZikiodRbhBVM6Jsc7qsQQJ34"

communications.subject: RE: California Public Records Act Request #P013291-100323
communications.communication:
Hi,

Many thanks for your help with this request! I really appreciate it.

Sincerely,
Christa Miller

communications.subject: RE: California Public Records Act Request #P013291-100323
communications.communication: Hi, I have a question about the POs you sent. Can you tell me what the different department codes stand for? I can infer PDEOCP = Police Department Emergency Operations Command Post, but what are PDDTSI, PDDTDC, PDADIM, and PDADBM?

communications.subject: [Records Center] PRA Request :: P013291-100323
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 

Dear Christa Miller, 
Per your request, the following are department codes and what it stands for: 
PDOECP - Chief of Police 
PDDTSI - Special Investigations 
PDDTDC - Deputy Chief 
PDADIM - Information Management 
PDADBM - Budget Management 
Thank you.

title: Maryland Freedom of Information Act Request: Student Privacy Documents  (Baltimore County Public Schools)

communications.subject: Maryland Public Information Act Request: Maryland Freedom of Information Act Request: Student Privacy Documents  (Baltimore County Public Schools)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Maryland Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

- A copy of any data release consent forms parents or students are asked to sign
- Any current policy documents or guidelines governing student data access and/or usage
- Any amendments made to those policy documents or guidelines governing student data access and/or usage from 2015-2023
- Documents outlining any school officials, third-party vendors, programs or applications with the ability to access, monitor, store, and/or transmit student data or metadata  
- All audits performed on behalf of BCPS to ensure compliance of  any school officials, third-party vendors, programs or applications with the ability to access, monitor, store, and/or transmit student data or metadata

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Edward Benjamin

communications.subject: RE: Government Records Access and Management Act Request: River Bottom Rd CAD Reports
communications.communication:
Hello,

Your request does not meet the requirements for filing a GRAMA request. I have attached the code that outlines what is required. We are happy to fill your request, we just ask that you fill out the form on our website. This would assure that you are providing all of the necessary information. We have linked our form below.

Thanks!

https://www.springville.org/police/services/request-for-records/

communications.subject: Records Request
communications.communication:
HI Patrick,

I was just looking over your records request and just wanted to clarify a few things. No our form does not make you pre-authorize costs of "at least $20." It starts at $10-$20. $10 being the cost per police report. $20 being the cost per 911 call, body cam, and photos. We chose those number methodically to match our fee schedule. Per UCA 63G-2-203 Fees "a Government entity may charge a reasonable fee to cover the governmental entity's actual cost of providing a record."

We have added the pre-authorization section on our online forms as some people fill them out without ever speaking with us or looking at the fee schedule. Having this section on the form assures that the public understands that there is a corresponding fee with requesting records.

In regards to your specific records request, there will be a fee of $10. Please let us know if you would like us to give you a call to complete payment and we will send you your police report.
Thanks!

[cid:image002.png@01D9FD06.3BE64C80]

communications.subject: RE: Government Records Access and Management Act Request: River Bottom Rd CAD Reports

Thank you,

Patrick Wells

communications.subject: RE: Government Records Access and Management Act Request: River Bottom Rd CAD Reports
communications.communication:
Good morning,

Thank you for your prompt attention to my recent GRAMA request concerning CAD reports for a specific address within a stipulated time period. However, it appears there has been a misunderstanding regarding the scope of my request.

My initial request sought CAD reports for each response to the specified address during the time period in question. The record you provided is a summary of the CAD reports available, and while it is informative, it does not fulfill the request as intended.

To clarify, I am seeking the complete CAD reports for each call, which would typically include CAD notes, unit assignments, response times, and any other pertinent details. I understand that there may be redactions for sensitive information, but the objective here is to receive a comprehensive view of each individual event rather than a summarized list.

I understand this was a simple miscommunication on the intent of the request and just wish to receive the intended records. Thank you for your time and attention to this matter.

Sincerely,

Patrick Wells

communications.subject: RE: Government Records Access and Management Act Request: River Bottom Rd CAD Reports
communications.communication:
Oh I must have misread the context on that. I will start preparing the full CAD logs.
Thanks

communications.subject: RE: Government Records Access and Management Act Request: River Bottom Rd CAD Reports
communications.communication:
We don’t invoice for reports. This is all we have to calculate costs. I would like to add, our staff time cost has actually increased to $27.10. I am only charging you half of the $24.41 which is our original staff time cost, as that was the cost at the time when I did the first Franke request.
Thanks!

communications.subject: RE: Government Records Access and Management Act Request: River Bottom Rd CAD Reports
communications.communication:
The provided billing sheet is exactly what I was looking for, thank you. 

I would like to request the re-consideration of the fees associated with this GRAMA request. 

Firstly, it seems there may be a misunderstanding about the classification of CAD reports. These are not the same as "police reports," and should not be billed as such. CAD reports are generally communication logs generated automatically during the course of a dispatcher’s duty, often with minimal intervention from human personnel. Charging $10 per CAD report as if they were comprehensive police reports seems inconsistent with your city’s comprehensive fee schedule. The listed staff time of one half hour only further emphasizes the point that the fee quoted is unreasonable.

Secondly, I believe that my request serves a significant public interest. The records I seek are pertinent to a story of great importance to the community, and their release would contribute to public understanding of the operations and activities of the government. As such, I believe a fee waiver would be appropriate in this case, and your refusal based on maintaining impartiality among media outlets does not seem to align with the spirit or letter of GRAMA.

Given the above factors, I kindly request that the fees associated with my GRAMA request be re-considered and waived. If this is not possible, I would like to escalate this matter and request the contact information for the Chief Administrative Officer for the Springville Police Department for a formal appeal. 

Thank you for your time and attention to this matter. I look forward to your response.

Sincerely,

Patrick Wells

communications.subject: RE: Government Records Access and Management Act Request: River Bottom Rd CAD Reports
communications.communication:
HI Patrick,

I do understand the difference between a CAD report and a police report. Though they aren’t the same thing, they cost the same, as we go through the same retrieval, redaction and certification process. With this being a decently large request of 10 reports, the 30 minutes is very fair, if not less time than usual. For out of state media representatives, per GRAMA code 63G-2-203(5), we start charging for our time as soon as we start working on the request. I have attached a screenshot that shows the timer for your request, with this email in the background. We receive many requests regarding the same cases daily. Everyone has understood the significance of us charging the fees to keep impartial for every media outlet, large or small. I hope you can understand where we are coming from, by wanting to give each media outlet the equal opportunity to obtain these records. If you change your mind on paying the fees, please let me know and we can do payment and I will get the reports sent over immediately. I have inserted the appeal instructions below.

“…following the procedures in UCA §63G-2-401. Please be sure to attach your initial request and denial letter when appealing. You may submit a request for appeal to the City Recorder, via mail at 110 S Main, Springville, UT 84663 within 30 days or via email at kcrane@springville.org.”

communications.subject: RE: Government Records Access and Management Act Request: River Bottom Rd CAD Reports
communications.communication:
Ms. Crane,

I am writing to formally appeal the fee imposed by the Springville Police Department in response to my Government Records Access and Management Act (GRAMA) request dated 10/9/23. The communications associated with this request are attached below this message. The fees imposed by Springville Police Dept, along with my contact information, are included in an attachment.

The request sought an electronic copy of the Computer Aided Dispatch (CAD) reports for all calls for service at 1803 E River Bottom Rd for the time period of January 1, 2017, to December 31, 2020. The Springville Police Department has classified CAD reports as "police reports," consequently levying a charge exceeding $100 based on the city's comprehensive fee schedule, which stipulates a $10 charge per police report.

First, I contend that CAD reports should not be classified as police reports. CAD reports are primarily data-driven, capturing basic information about calls for service, and are generally not completed by police officers. They differ significantly from police reports, which are narrative and provide detailed accounts of incidents. The reclassification and charging for each CAD report as a police report is not only misrepresentative but also unduly increases the cost of obtaining these public records, contrary to the spirit of GRAMA which aims to promote transparency and ease of access to public records.

Additionally, I request that the fees associated with this GRAMA request be waived entirely, given the significant public interest surrounding the events at the aforementioned address. The Springville Police Department’s rationale to decline a fee waiver to maintain impartiality across media outlets is flawed. Impartiality is not achieved by denying fee waivers to all, but rather, would be accomplished through the provision of fee waivers to all media outlets, thereby leveling the playing field and truly adhering to the spirit of GRAMA which encourages public access to information. Utah’s GRAMA, under Section 63G-2-203(4)(a), encourages fee waivers when releasing the records primarily benefits the public rather than a person. I assert that the routine denial of fee waivers based not on the merits of the request, but on a mistaken believe that this encourages impartiality, is in violation of GRAMA. The national discourse surrounding the incidents in question unmistakably demonstrates that the release of these records primarily serves the public interest.

Therefore, in alignment with the provisions and the spirit of GRAMA, I strongly appeal for a full waiver of the fees associated with this request or, at the very least, a significant reduction by reclassifying the CAD reports and charging only for staff time.

I am willing to discuss this appeal further at your convenience. Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

Sincerely,

Patrick Wells

Attached is a copy of our Response to your GRAMA request.
Thanks,

Sincerely,

Parker Higgins, FOIA The Dead

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL EMAIL] -  RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: Frank Lary, FBI file
communications.communication:
Thank you for contacting foipaquestions@fbi.gov.  Please check the status of your FOIPA Request at http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on "Check Status of Your FOI/PA Request" on the right side of the page, and follow the instructions below.

Check the Status of Your FOIPA Request
If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-0] please enter [1234567-000] into the system. If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-1] please enter [1234567-001] into the system. If you have any questions about the status of your FOIPA request, please e-mail foipaquestions@fbi.gov.

FIND STATUS OF FOIPA- Request statuses are updated weekly

Please enter the whole FOIPA number-Example: [1234567-000]

FOIPA:
Results will show the Request Number, Case Type and Process Description shown below:
FOIPA:
1234567-000

Case Type:
FOIPA

Process Description (Will display the current progress of the request)
The FBI's FOIPA Program is searching the FBI's indices for potentially responsive documents.
You may be contacted via formal letter for all fees and/or negotiation issues that may apply.

NOTE: Recent requests are entered into the FOIPA database in the order that they are received. Before you can check the status, you must have received correspondence assigning a FOIPA request number and the information transferred to the online database. Status information is updated weekly. If a request has been closed within the last six months the online database will display the following: The FOIPA number entered has been closed, and appropriate correspondence has been sent to the address on file.

Estimated Dates of Completion
Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Complex requests are further divided into medium, large, and extra-large sub-tracks based upon request size.  Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  Currently, simple track cases average approximately 104 days from the date of receipt for processing.  Our complex requests in the medium processing track are currently averaging 853 days, large processing track are currently averaging approximately 1,786 days, and extra-large processing track are currently averaging 2,500 days for processing.

Respectfully,

Public Information Officer
FBI - Information Management Division
200 Constitution Drive
Winchester, VA  22602
O: (540) 868-4593
E: foipaquestions@fbi.gov<mailto:foipaquestions@fbi.gov>

Do you have further questions about the FOI/PA process? Visit us at http://www.fbi.gov/foia

Please check the status of your request online at https://vault.fbi.gov/fdps-1/@@search-fdps    Status updates are performed on a weekly basis.

Note:  This is a non-emergency email address.  If this is an emergency, please call 911 directly.  If you need to report a tip for immediate action, please contact FBI Tips at http://tips.fbi.gov/ or reach out to your local field office.

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

All contracts, licenses, MOUs, MOAs, data agreements, letters of intent, and other agreement documents between the Fort Lauderdale Police Department and SoundThinking. Please include all relevant documents for every SoundThinking product or program that the Department is using, has agreed to use, or used any time since January 1, 2020.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

Sincerely,

communications.subject: RE: Florida Sunshine Law Request: Sunshine Law Request: Data for Good
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

On August 1st, SoundThinking published a press release stating that the Fort Lauderdale Police Department had agreed to implement SoundThinking's Data for Good program. Please see the press release at the end of this request.

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

All contracts, licenses, MOUs, MOAs, data agreements, letters of intent, and other agreement documents between the Fort Lauderdale Police Department and SoundThinking. Please include all relevant documents for every SoundThinking product or program that the Department is using, has agreed to use, or used any time since January 1, 2020.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

PRESS RELEASE: 
FREMONT, Calif., Aug. 01, 2023 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- SoundThinking, Inc. (Nasdaq: SSTI) (formerly ShotSpotter), a leading provider of public safety technology solutions, today announced that the Fort Lauderdale Police Department has agreed to implement SoundThinking’s Data for Good program. The program’s official launch on August 1st coincides with National Night Out (NNO), an annual community-building campaign that promotes police-community partnerships.

Data for Good is a community-focused program that enables law enforcement agencies to share precision data about where and when gun violence occurs with non-law enforcement organizations. SoundThinking helps law enforcement customers identify offices of violence prevention, schools, city and county public health departments and other community organizations to receive gunfire data. By indicating where gunfire and potential trauma may be occurring, appropriate community resources can be deployed to help prevent future violence, address root causes, and provide assistance to those adversely impacted by exposure to persistent gun violence.

“By embracing the Data for Good Program, we can now pivot to a holistic community-based approach to violence prevention, outreach, and community engagement,” said Fort Lauderdale Police Chief Patrick Lynn. “This fosters a sense of ownership and collective responsibility for community safety rather than relying solely on punitive measures. By bridging the gap between law enforcement and the community, we can co-create effective solutions that deter crime and nurture an environment where individuals can thrive and reach their full potential.” 

Fort Lauderdale Police Department joins agencies in Miami-Dade County, FL, Baton Rouge, LA, Springfield, IL, and Mobile, AL, in implementing Data for Good programs. Through the program, these areas actively address gun violence and improve community ties with law enforcement.

"As a company, we believe that by harnessing data-driven insights and looking at them through a different lens, our customers can allocate resources to those impacted by the traumatic impact of gunfire,” said Alfred Lewers Jr., Senior Director of Trauma Response & Community Engagement at SoundThinking. “Our Data for Good program aims to support our customers’ public health approach to gun violence reduction, and we are thrilled that the Fort Lauderdale Police Department is now among a growing list of agencies best-positioned to support community partners working to proactively and effectively address the root causes of gun violence.”

To learn more about how ShotSpotter assists community-based and civic programs, please visit our Data for Good page.

SOURCE: https://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2023/08/01/2715842/0/en/Fort-Lauderdale-Community-Based-and-Public-Health-Groups-to-Benefit-From-SoundThinking-s-Data-For-Good-Program.html

title: Communication with Apple Inc. regarding Digital Driver's License

communications.subject: Arizona Public Records Law Request: Communication with Apple Inc. regarding Digital Driver's License
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Arizona Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Public Information Request
Arizona Department of Transportation
Public Information Office
1655 W. Jackson Street
Mail Drop 126F
Phoenix, AZ 85007

Subject: Public Records Request under the Arizona Public Records Law - Communication with Apple Inc. regarding Digital Driver's License

Dear Public Information Office,

I am writing to submit a formal public records request under the Arizona Public Records Law, requesting access to records held by the Arizona Department of Transportation (ADOT). Specifically, I am seeking information related to any communication between ADOT and Apple Inc. regarding the development, implementation, or management of the Digital Driver's License system in Arizona.

In accordance with the Arizona Public Records Law, I request access to the following information within the specified timeframe:

Any written correspondence, including letters, emails, memoranda, and faxes, exchanged between the Arizona Department of Transportation and Apple Inc. regarding the Digital Driver's License system between January 1, 2019, and the date of processing this public records request.

Any meeting minutes, agendas, or summaries of meetings, including phone or video conferences, held between representatives of the Arizona Department of Transportation and Apple Inc. regarding the Digital Driver's License system during the same period specified above.

Any contracts, agreements, or memoranda of understanding entered into between the Arizona Department of Transportation and Apple Inc. regarding the development, implementation, or management of the Digital Driver's License system.

Any reports, presentations, or studies prepared by Apple Inc. or shared with the Arizona Department of Transportation pertaining to the Digital Driver's License system.

Any policies, guidelines, or directives issued by the Arizona Department of Transportation in relation to the use of Apple Inc.'s technology or services for the Digital Driver's License system.

To support this request, I would like to reference the following provisions of the Arizona Public Records Law:

Arizona Revised Statutes, Title 39, Chapter 1, Article 2 - This statute outlines the public's right of access to government records and sets forth the requirements for public records requests.
I kindly request that you do not withhold or redact any responsive documents without valid legal grounds. If any redactions are made, I request that you provide an index of the redacted material with specific citations to the applicable exemptions under the Arizona Public Records Law.

Furthermore, I request that you take appropriate measures to ensure the preservation of all responsive records. Please refrain from deleting, destroying, or altering any documents that fall within the scope of this request.

Please note that this request covers both electronic and physical records, regardless of format, including but not limited to paper documents, emails, attachments, text messages, and audio or video recordings.

If access to the requested records is denied or only partially granted, please cite the specific legal exemptions or reasons for withholding the information as required by the Arizona Public Records Law.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Law enforcement informal and formal settlement data and reports
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Materials related to and sufficient to show all instances of alleged and actual inappropriate or illegal behavior or actions resulting in compensation or expenditures involving this agency.

Responsive materials include records of all settlements (formal and informal) and payments to which this agency was or is a party for the period from January 1, 2010 through the date this request is processed. Responsive materials include those for matters and legal claims resolved prior to the initiation of any litigation.

In particular, materials responsive to this request include all reports, lists, databases, spreadsheets, and other documentation detailing incidents of legal claims or other allegations requiring compensation for claimants, attorneys, or any other party.

If spreadsheets or similar documents are available in response to this request, please provide all segregable data, including but not limited to:

The nature of the claim or legal matter
The claimant and other parties involved
The relevant case and tracking numbers for court and internal systems
The date the lawsuit was served or litigation commenced
The final disposition or current status of the case, including whether a case is still pending
The amount spent to date as a result of the legal engagement
The amount paid to any parties related to the legal claim, including any city payout and any non-monetary compensation

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

After reviewing your request, the Risk Department believes every claim for damage filed from 1/1/2010 to 10/4/2023 is "alleged and actual inappropriate or illegal behavior or actions resulting in compensation or expenditures involving this agency." 
If you are seeking a copy of every claim for damage file from 2010 through 2023, it could potentially take many years to fulfill your request. However, to narrow and expedite your request, a spreadsheet of all claim for damages can be provide to you for you to identify which specific claim for damages you are seeking. We have begun assembling material requested and to determine whether any of the documents are exempt from disclosure and we anticipate that we should have responsive documents on or before November 1, 2023 . If there are questions, or delays we will contact you accordingly. 
In the meantime, if you should have any questions, please feel free to contact me. 

Regards, 

Lisa  Anderson 
Public Disclosure Analyst, CPRO 
Public Records Office 
(253) 231-0238

title: Open Records Request: Ohio Violent Crime Reduction Grant

communications.subject: Ohio Open Records Law Request: Open Records Request: Ohio Violent Crime Reduction Grant
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

According to a press release from Gov. Mike DeWine's office, the Cleveland Division of Police received a grant of $355,400 as part of the Ohio Violent Crime Reduction Grant program: https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/OHIOGOVERNOR/2023/02/22/file_attachments/2416264/Violent%20Crime%20Reduction%20Program%20Grant%20Summaries%20through%20R12.pdf

Pursuant to the Ohio Open Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

A copy of all documents, including but not limited to, applications, agreements, and reporting documents for the Cleveland Division of Police's $355,400 grant as part of the Ohio Violent Crime Reduction Grant program described in the press release linked above.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

e
